text:
I am probably missing something very obvious. Can someone help me understand this?
```foo_string = "foo"
foo_dict = Dict("f"=>0, "o"=>0)```
this:
```haskey(foo_dict, "f")```
returns: `true`

but why does
```for char in foo_string
    print(char, " ", haskey(foo_dict, char))
end```
returns this?
```f false
o false
o false```
What is a Julian way to check if a character in a string is in a dictionary key?

Thanks in advance.

elements.text: I am probably missing something very obvious. Can someone help me understand this?

f false
o false
o false

What is a Julian way to check if a character in a string is in a dictionary key?

Thanks in advance.

text: Can we cross post this publicly to <https://discourse.julialang.org|Discourse> for further visibility? React with :bridge: on the message above to approve. <https://github.com/JuliaCommunity/SlackBridge/blob/main/README.md#faq|More info here>

Success, it has been cross posted <https://discourse.julialang.org/t/55193| to Discourse>. Keep and eye out on Discourse for responses and please add an answer there once you are satisfied with the solution so others can benefit as well. Happy debugging!
isn't it because the dict has strings as keys, while you iterate over chars?

elements.text: isn't it because the dict has strings as keys, while you iterate over chars?

text: I mean, you should replace your dict instantiation by `Dict('f'=>0, 'o'=>0)` and then I think it will output what you expect it to.
